--- pisharath_k <pisharath_k@...> wrote:
> Thanks for your suggestions everyone (please see my
> original mail 
> attached below).
> 
> But the problem I am having is this - the classes
> are complex, hence 
> constructing classes with test data (so I can check
> against the data 
> read from file) is very cumbersome. Also, with
> equals() method I 
> cannot know which data member in the class actually
> caused a mis-
> match, since I assert only at the class level.
> 
> This is why I am thinking what to do... hope this
> clarifies the 
> problem. Any suggestions would be appreciated.
> Thanks again for your 
> help so far.
> 
> - krishnan

Well, you could have the helper keep a list of the
problems that equals() encountered.  Then you could
ask it what the problem was.  Example (java) of code
for your test case:

if (!helper.equals(testObject)) {

   fail(helper.equalFailureMessage());
}

Then you could make the helper equals() check each
item and keep a list of errors.

Or something like that.

-Eric
